answers.answer: Hi and welcome to the community.  We are "famous" here for the support we can provide, so you've come to the right place..........As to your food - do you get the option of choosing what you get?  If so, then be sure to pick as much fresh fruits and veggies as you can (if, when available).  If most of the food is canned, go the "low sodium" versions whenever possible; opt for sugar free as much as you can.  Limit the amount of pasta and bread as much as you can or make sure you opt for whole grain whenever possible.  For the meats - there are delicious ways to prepare meals using ground beef (a lot of us are going for less expensive cuts these days) - but after browning it for a dish, make sure you drain it well before mixing in other ingredients.  Grilling or broiling, both ground beef and pork, is preferable to frying whenever possible, except when using in other dishes, such as casseroles, etc.  You don't mention dairy - but try to get enough to get at least 3 servings of low/no fat dairy daily.  This includes milk, yogurt, cheese, etc.  Also, eggs are high in protein for very few calories.  Also very important, is to limit your portion sizes.  It's a good idea to keep a food diary (MedHelp has an excellent one) so you can see exactly how many calories you are consuming each day.For exercise - you might do best to walk since you have arthritis, but there are other exercises that you can work into, that might even help your arthritis.  A brisk 30 minute walk per day is great or aim for around 10,000 steps per day - you'd need a pedometer to know for sure.  If you can't do a full 30 minute walk at one time, break it up into 3 - 10 minute walks.  You can also do a computer search for exercise videos that you can watch for free - YouTube and spark people both have some.  Yoga is fantastic - it's low impact and helps strengthen your core muscles, plus stretching and strength.  An exercise and weight tracker is good also (MedHelp has good ones).Just a few suggestions to think about and research.  You are right that losing weight could bring down your cholesterol levels, but can't guarantee you could get off med.  Eating right and losing weight, would also help with the diabetes - again can't say for sure you could get off med, but it might help to cut down - I'm not a doctor, so I can't know for sure.Good luck and keep posting so we know how you are doing.

question: For most of my life I was really fit.  When I got married,32 years ago, I was 115lbs.  I started putting on a lot of weight due to stress, a lot of stress.  I'm a good 65+ lbs. overweight not and have high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes.  my problem, and I'm not looking for anyone to feel sorry for me, our finances are soooo bad that most of our food comes from a church.  Unfortunately, it's a lot of carbs, pasta, bread, and high fat meats like ground beef and pork.  Exercise is a bit of a toughy too cause I have arthritis, and fibromyalgia.  I do play some disc golf a few times a week which gives me a good mile walk.  Does anyone have any suggestions?  I feel at a loss cause if I attempt certain excercises it puts me down for days because of the joint pain.  Help.  I know if I can get rid of this weight the blood pressure, diabetes and high cholesterol will go away and I can get off all the meds.  I just went through withdrawal from pain medications, can't afford the cholesterol meds but want to get off the high blood pressure and diabetes meds.  I figure if I get a good support group and have to hold myself accountable it might be easier.  Thanks
title: really need help and support
